Award.AbstractNarration:
AST-0908276
Campins

This project is a three-year spectroscopic study of 20 Cybele and Hilda asteroids. Cybeles and Hildas orbit between two significantly different populations of primitive asteroids, those in the main belt and those in the Jupiter Trojan clouds. Many Cybele and Hilda asteroids can now be reached by near-infrared and mid-infrared spectroscopy, which is diagnostic of the mineralogy of the asteroid surfaces. This study will determine if Cybele and Hilda asteroids show surface characteristics similar to Jupiter Trojans, and will therefore test the recent dynamical models that argue that many asteroids in this region are actually captured objects from the primordial transneptunian belt. This team has already demonstrated the potential of this observational approach.

Undergraduate and graduate students, some female or members of other under-represented groups, will be directly involved in the research. The methods and results of this research will be incorporated into undergraduate and graduate courses, and the results will also inform public outreach activities.

Institution.Name: The University of Central Florida Board of Trustees
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CENTRAL FLORIDA BOARD OF TRUSTEES, THE

Performance_Institution.Name: The University of Central Florida Board of Trustees

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
we obtained spectra of asteroids in the main-belt and in the Cybele and Hilda regions. We have carried out observing runs from the Galileo telescope in La Palma, Spain and the Infrared Telescope Facility (IRTF) in Hawaii. 

This project has been a great success. After our report in 2012, we have published eight more refereed papers, listed below, for a total of 27 refereed publications since receiving this grant.

This project focused on spectroscopic observations of asteroids and involved five undergraduate students (Ms. Allison Bratcher, Ms. Alexandra Betrone-Harpst, Ms. Christine Comfort, Mr. Bradley Hoover, and Ms. Sarah Tuttle).  More specifically, the participants gained experience in astronomical observations, data reduction and analysis, and technical writing.

 

Outreach Activities: a) I organized and oversaw an international event at UCF simultaneous with the close approach Earth  of asteroid 2012 DA14, on January 15, 2013. This event was a great success, it was attended by over 800 people (standing room only), it was covered live on National Public radio and six local and national TV stations and other local, national, and international news outlets c) I was interviewed approximately 50 times by news organizations mainly about the asteroid DA14 close approach Earth discovery of ice and organics on a second asteroid d) I lectured at several of UCF's Robinson Observatory public nights, with attendances ranging from 20 to 200 people in one night c) d) I organized and lectured at a community day at the Orlando Science Center dedicated to informing and involving the community about asteroids.


Last Modified: 01/24/2014
Modified by: Humberto Campins
